valerie 04/07/2023 10:42 AM
HIP 81: Minimum Device Onboarding Fee Author(s): @groot , @Max - Just Max Start Date: 2023-04-07 Category: Economic Original HIP PR: https://github.com/helium/HIP/issues/606 Tracking Issue: https://github.com/helium/HIP/issues/612 Summary This HIP proposes to set a minimum onboarding fee for Hotspots in the subDAO structure. This HIP also proposes that Hotspots for which the minimum onboarding fee has not been burned are not eligible for rewards from the subDAO. The minimum onboarding fee will be dynamically defined as $40 and will follow the same halving schedule as HNT and will therefore start at $20. Motivation A minimum onboarding fee is necessary to: 1. Stop subDAOs from arbitrarily onboarding Hotspots. 2. Prevent nuisance attacks against subDAOs and the Helium DAO. HIP51 has described the onboarding of Hotspots but has not made this explicit. Hotspots for which the minimum onboarding fee has not been burnt are not eligible for rewards. SubDAOs attempting to bypass this requirement will be subject to slashing. Rendered View https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0081-minimum-onboarding-fee.md (edited)

mcharliem 04/07/2023 5:37 PM
Delegating to the favored subdao definitely gives you diminishing returns the more that’s delegated, but I think that’s the point. In your 80/20 example, you would get more for your money by delegating to the 20, but that means the market is implying that the 80 subdao’s future prospects are even better than the 4 to 1 the 80/20 implies.
17:39
In other words, assuming people are acting rationally, people are being offered an excess amount of the 20 subdao’s tokens, and they’re still choosing the 80 subdao’s tokens because they think its prospects are that much better.

ferebee 04/08/2023 3:11 AM
I’m looking at how the action items mentioned by @hashc0de in his post above might be brought together. In my view, this is a bit of a shit sandwich from a technical perspective, but in the end, it is urgent that we vote on a proposal that can pass before transition, so it is what it is. With that in mind, I’d like to ask @Max - Just Max and @groot in particular what your view is concerning the A score in light of different onboarding fees. Specifically, Data-Only Hotspots are defined in IOT. Their onboarding fee is currently $10. AFAIK 6,000+ such Hotspots have been onboarded, and some number are currently active and transmitting data. The minimum onboarding fee as proposed in HIP-81 and referenced in hashc0de’s list of action items is higher than $10. Questions: - Should existing Data-Only Hotspots continue to receive rewards as is, or would they be required to backpay the higher onboarding fee? - If they don’t backpay the higher fee, should they count towards the Utility Score? - Will additional Data-Only Hotspots be permitted to onboard by paying a fee that is below the minimum as specified in HIP-81?

ferebee 04/08/2023 9:30 AM
After considering all the options, I have decided to propose a PR to HIP-78 which attempts to address all the issues which @hashc0de has identified. As I recall, you have said that you actually like HIP-78. I was fairly satisfied with HIP-78 until it turned out that nobody was actually going to pay the fees in a lump sum, as had been proposed. So that basically rugged the original idea. Now, it looks like you and groot have assembled some degree of consensus around an alternative proposal that is also based on the Score of HIP-51, just like HIP-78 was, and have found that the individual gateway owners woud be willing to pay the missing $40 onboard fees specified in HIP-53. Your proposal, HIP-81, also includes the square root on the veHNT term, which JMF brought up to me as I was working on the edit to HIP-78 that became HIP-80. Congratulations on achieving some degree of consensus on that, at least. Now therefore, my suggestion is that I revise HIP-78 to include these provisions, which you have put into HIP-81. I would add you as coauthors. If we can agree on a final version, I will then ask Valerie to reopen HIP-78, and will retract HIP-80. To be clear, I still believe HIP-80 is superior for multiple reasons, but my overriding goal is to get a vote passed on something that gives us the most stable foundation possible for further development. I can only do this if I fully understand both your @groot and your @Max - Just Max positions, so I can include them clearly and correctly. I do not intend to leave any ambiguities open that I can identify. (edited)

16:59
I’ve been reading HIP-81 for a bit now, and have some questions.
16:59
. 1. HIP-81 defines that Hotspots must pay onboarding fees in order to receive “rewards”. Does “rewards” refer to PoC rewards, Data Transfer rewards, or both? (edited)
16:59
. 2. Per HIP-81, the DAO prohibits subDAOs from paying DNT rewards to Hotspots which have not paid the minimum onboarding fee. Does this respect the principle that the Helium DAO should not interfere in matters of subDAO governance? (edited)
16:59
. 3. MOBILE Hotspots have not yet paid an onboarding fee. The onboarding fee currently specified by HIP-53 for MOBILE Hotspots, but not collected by the existing implementation, is $40. What mechanism will be used to enable MOBILE Hotspots to pay an onboarding fee? (edited)
16:59
. 4. After the transition to Solana, onboarding fees and the mechanism for their payment will be a matter of subDAO governance. What is the expected timeframe until subDAO governance procedures will be established, so the subDAO can specify the fee and a method for its payment? Will any MOBILE Hotspots be onboarded before then, such that they may count towards the MOBILE Utility Score A factor? How? (edited)
17:00
. 5. HIP-81 specifies that, among other devices, LTE/5G radios for Helium MOBILE “must” be onboarded separately as “devices”. How is this enforced? What are the consequences for a Hotspot owner who connects radios to a MOBILE Hotspot, but does not pay onboarding fees for the radios? Do radios (“devices”) count towards the DAO Utility Score of MOBILE in the same way as Hotspots? If the radios are “devices” but not “Hotspots”, do they obey the same minimum fee schedule as Hotspots, as specified in the Summary of HIP-81? Otherwise, how will the actual fee per radio be set? (edited)
17:00
. 6. If the MOBILE subDAO may set arbitrary onboarding fees per gateway and radio, and considering the hypothetical scenario that the subDAO could charge onboarding fees of $1,000 or more for high-performance radios, which themselves might cost $10,000 or more, how is this expected to affect the Utility Score of MOBILE vs. IOT, compared to HIP-51 or HIP-80? (edited)
17:00
. Implementation (edited)
17:00
The current implementation does not support summing the onboarding fee paid by each active hotspot. It operates on the simple product:  (number of active Hotspots) times (onboarding fee) which corresponds to the mathematical formula displayed in HP-81. However, this contradicts the text of HIP-81, which requires the calculation of the Score to consider the set of active Hotspots, then establish the fee originally paid by each, then take the sum of all fees. (The existing implementation can’t do this.) Among other situations, this will become extremely important in the period when zero legacy MOBILE Hotspots have paid their onboarding fees, but new Hotspots are onboarded which do pay fees, as it will then be critical to determine which of the “active” Hotspots contribute to the Score, and which do not. Until a compliant implementation can be developed, which of the two contradictory calculations given in HIP-81 shall be used to determine the distribution of HNT between the subDAOs? Is there a timeframe for the development of an implementation that is compliant with the text of HIP-81?
Max - Just Max 04/08/2023 5:27 PM
1) HIP pretty clearly POC rewards and any other non-data transfer rewards . 2) No you must onboard a device with an DC burn to participate in the Helium network. This allows helium DAO to extract value back from the subDAOs before they have data transfer 3) slashing 4) this only matters for Mobile and HIPs 51 and 53 broadly give those powers to the foundation. We don’t foresee lack of payment being an issue for mobile and are confident this will get sorted prior to migration. 5) it’s not enforced. That is simply a recommendation and up to the subDAO. 6) we don’t really care at the HeliumDAO level if 1,000 devices are onboarded for $20 each or 1 device for $20,000 as long as the DC gets burned. The subDAOs will use their offchain oracles to report a number. If Mobile decides to have a dynamic onboard rate by radio type it is easy to audit if the reported number is correct. @KeithR has been reporting daily updates on radios, their types, and their online status. All of the above are stated in the HIP. I appreciate the feedback and questions. (edited)

Max - Just Max 04/09/2023 9:26 AM
Just want to reiterate to the questions about architecture, this HIP actually doesn’t require any engineering work that wasn’t already being done. To be a compliant subDAO under Helium DAO you must be running these oracles either way per HIP-51: All subDAOs must operate Oracles for their networks. Each subDAO Oracle runs software to calculate DNP specific items (e.g., all the Proof-of-Coverage code that exists on the current LoRaWAN network to determine Hotspot rewards) and the subDAO Oracles who have staked DNTs come to consensus on these calculations and submit them to the Helium Network. (edited)
Hans 04/09/2023 9:48 AM
I've though a lot about this issue over the past few days. In my view it looks as if HIP80 is trying to best-fit an algorithm by using arbitrary price floors and ceilings to create a "soft landing" for the IoT subDAO. They are doing so by using projections and models that are highly subjective and prone to error. Whereas HIP 81 is simply correcting the issue of the onboarding fee and allowing market forces to determine the emissions rate based on market-driven principles. This creates a more resilient network long-term because it can dynamically respond to the future market conditions. I see HIP80's author's reasoning of giving a 1st mover advantage to the IoT network, but it's a inefficient way to solve the issue of IoT's reduced emissions post HIP70/51. (edited)

ferebee 04/09/2023 3:34 PM
Right. Onboarded Hotspots stay onboarded. MOBILE Hotspots aren’t actually onboarded to MOBILE yet. They need to pay to onboard to MOBILE under HIP-81, or will be grandfathered in under HIP-80. All new Hotspots need to pay. Onboardings are currently still $40 for all new Hotspots, but they can be dropped to $5 by each subDAO under HIP-80, or to $20 now under HIP-81 and $10 from August. Under HIP-81 there is an incentive (Utility Score) for subDAOs to keep the fee higher. Under HIP-80 there isn’t an economic incentive, so subDAOs will decide based only on security and other factors.

Max - Just Max 04/09/2023 7:35 PM
My main issue with the the square root of V is V was meant to be the communities way of voting with their wallet about which networks would be the best. The winner take all scenario doesn’t play out because DNTs can have staking and burn functions that make them have value other than their redemption value from the treasury. I don’t personally hate the square root, I just don’t see the need to change it and could see the argument that linear function works better. We attempted to add something like V^.9 to blunt the score but weren’t able to reach consensus on an exponent we liked so, in the interest of timing, decided to omit that from the HIP and figure it out after the migration.

lebo 04/09/2023 10:18 PM
What about the fee already indirectly paid by the owner to the manufacturer when he bought the hotspot, when this hotspot is not onboarded yet ? It won't be lowered, as the owner won't be refunded. Is that business good only for makers ? We need to protect buyers ! What about the fee when a maker has shut down his business ? As if another maker like Nebra provides a solution, they still ask the hotspot owners to pay this onboarding fee again ! We need to protect buyers ! A solution to the 2 issues above would be that, instead of an onboarding fee paid or not by the maker when the user onboards the hotspot, then instead it would be a prepaid making fee, locked into an onboarding pool, and paid by the maker as soon as they shipped/sell the unit ? (could be a NFT tied to the hotspot NFT). This would protect the buyers and owners, instead of protecting the makers. If the fee is lowered, some part could be refund to the owner when he finally onboard the HS. This pool would grow, as the big issue for buyers is to find hosts. Therefore the onboarding can happen many many months or years after a unit is purchased. We need to protect buyers ! (edited)

Max - Just Max 04/10/2023 12:15 PM
Groot and I spoke with the devs today, specifically Noah with Abhay also on the call. The initial plan was to do this using offchain oracles, just as POC is planning on being done. While the offchain method works, due to the time crunch of the migration, at their recommendation we will be updating the HIP today, adding a grace period of August 1 for all burn to occur. In the interim, for simplicity we will be using an assumed $40 onboard fee and count all FFi and Bobcat 5G gateways that are active towards both subDAOs, regardless of how many radios are attached to them in the DAO utility score. If the mobile subDAO still cannot onboard radios by that date, the treasury will be slashed to make up for that assumed onboard fee. Myself, and the foundation do not see the slashing as a necessary action and are confident that the burn will occur according to whatever payment schedule the Mobile subDAO decides through its own governance. (edited)

I tried to give some visuals on that but was lambasted for my apparently wrong assumptions, yet nobody was able to say why they were wrong and what they should've been so I pretty much left it there. With HIP80 there is a floor value for both IOT and MOBILE and those will increase the HNT going to MOBILE short term. HIP81 has no such floor but will allow MOBILE to earn its part of the pie when it starts doing something. HIP81 recognizes the $40M burn IOT did in the form of onboarding fees and places a value on that instead of the floor.

ferebee 04/12/2023 1:50 PM
More precisely I should have said, HNT will only be emitted to HST holders and to treasuries. The point of the treasury is, indeed, to exchange DNT (MOBILE or IOT) for HNT at the treasury floor price. The DNT is burned in that transaction, decreasing the total supply of the DNT, which may then indirectly affect the treasury floor price.

Hans 04/15/2023 7:50 AM
The truth is, the driving force behind Helium's potential growth will likely be the mobile sector, rather than IoT. Although IoT has a significant market presence, it faces intense competition and has limited growth potential due to low pricing. IoT alone cannot provide the necessary growth to achieve a substantial increase in the network's reach. The mobile ecosystem holds the key to success, but HIP 80 may hinder its growth by disproportionately allocating rewards to the IoT subDAO during the mid-phase of MOBILE's deployment, potentially discouraging people from deploying hardware in the mobile sector.
07:52
HIP80 is a shackle on emissions, and it's going to be a drag on growth. I understand that we want to "protect" the IOT network, but the ultimate goal is creating value for HNT overall regardless of the network. And that value generation will be hindered by artificially supporting one network over the other.
Hans

ferebee 04/15/2023 9:20 AM
I’ll just point out that a new subDAO will be brought on by a new HIP, which can set new rules. It will probably be easy to find consensus to give a new subDAO less of a subsidy, if desired. Increasing the subsidy, on the other hand, will probably be difficult. So we’re not setting ourselves up for uncontrollable risk, with HIP-80 or HIP-81.
